crfModuleGuideline: NMD Clinical Outcome Recommendations by Domain and Classification
description: Contains the Clinical Outcome instrument/scale recommendations as recommended by the NMD CDE Working Group

This CRF Module is the epilepsy-specific version of the General Prior and Concomitant Medications CRF Module. Its purpose is to record all medications a participant/ subject was taking during the study and any period of time prior to the study as dictated by the study protocol.

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant use indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator of whether the participant/subject reported taking any medications during the time period relevant to the study protocol
cdes.questionText: Did the participant/subject take any medications _ days before or during the study
cdes.instructions: Indicate whether the participant/subject took any non-study anti epileptic drugs (AEDs) during the study. Core for all prospective intervention and observation studies
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant use indicator

cdes.cdeName: Medication non-anti-epileptic drug prior or concomitant use day count
cdes.definitionDescription: The numeric count of days a non-anti-epileptic drug (NAED) was taken before or during a study.
cdes.questionText: Number of days before or during the study
cdes.instructions: No instructions available
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Medication non-anti-epileptic drug log line number
cdes.definitionDescription: The referenced line number of an entry on the non-anti-epileptic drug (NAED) plasma concentration log.
cdes.questionText: Line number
cdes.instructions: No instructions available
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant name
cdes.definitionDescription: Name of the prior/concomitant agent or drug administered.
cdes.questionText: Generic Name of Medication
cdes.instructions:
Record the generic or brand name of the anti epileptic drug.
Core for all prospective intervention  and observation studies
cdes.referrences: RXNorm (http://www.nlm.nih.gov/research/umls/rxnorm/)
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant RXNorm code
cdes.definitionDescription: Code for name of the prior/concomitant agent or drug administered.
cdes.questionText: Generic Name of Medication
cdes.instructions:
Code the verbatim name of the medication using RXNorm.
Core for all prospective intervention  and observation studies
cdes.referrences: RXNorm (http://www.nlm.nih.gov/research/umls/rxnorm/)
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant RXNorm code

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant dose frequency
cdes.definitionDescription: Frequency of use of a prior/concomitant medication.
cdes.questionText: Dose Frequency
cdes.permissibleDescription: twice daily;three times a day;four times a day;every 2 hours;every 4 hours;every 6 hours;every 8 hours;one dose in morning;one dose in evening;once daily;alternating day (every other day);at bedtime;as needed;Other, specify;unknown;Not applicable;
cdes.instructions: Record the frequency based on the dosing schedule recorded on the CRF
cdes.referrences: CDISC SDTM Frequency Terminology (Code C71113) - http://evs.nci.nih.gov/ftp1/CDISC/SDTM/
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant dose frequency

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant PRN average monthly frequency
cdes.definitionDescription: Average frequency per month for medications that are taken on an as needed basis (PRN)
cdes.questionText: Average frequency
cdes.instructions: Record the average number of times per month the PRN medication is taken
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant PRN average monthly frequency

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant dose
cdes.definitionDescription: Dose of prior/concomitant medication taken per administration.
cdes.questionText: Total Daily Dose or PRN Dose
cdes.instructions: Record the dose of AED the participant/subject was prescribed to take. Core for all prospective intervention and observation studies. The following abbreviations are recommended to capture dose units: g = gram;gr = grain;gtt = drop;mcg = microgram;mcL = microliter;mg = milligram;mL = milliliter;oz = ounce;SPY = spray/squirt;supp = suppository;TBSP = tablespoon;Sp = teaspoon;OTH = other, specify;UNK= Unknown
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant dose unit of measure
cdes.definitionDescription: Dosage unit of measure of the prior or concomitant medication administered.
cdes.questionText: Units
cdes.instructions: Record the unit for dose of AED the participant/subject was prescribed to take. Core for all prospective intervention and observacation studies. Examples of dose units include: g = gram; gr = grain; gtt = drop; mcg = microgram; mcL = microliter; mg = milligram; mL = milliliter; oz = ounce; SPY = spray/squirt; supp = suppository; TBSP = Tablespoon; tsp = teaspoon; OTH = other, specify; UNK = unknown
cdes.referrences: Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM) - http://unitsofmeasure.org/
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant dose unit of measure

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant dose other text
cdes.definitionDescription: The free-text field related to 'Medication prior or concomitant dose unit of measure' specifying other text. Dosage unit of measure of the prior or concomitant medication administered.
cdes.questionText: Other, specify
cdes.instructions: Record the unit for dose of AED the participant/subject was prescribed to take. Core for all prospective intervention and observacation studies. Examples of dose units include: g = gram; gr = grain; gtt = drop; mcg = microgram; mcL = microliter; mg = milligram; mL = milliliter; oz = ounce; SPY = spray/squirt; supp = suppository; TBSP = Tablespoon; tsp = teaspoon; OTH = other, specify; UNK = unknown
cdes.referrences: Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM) - http://unitsofmeasure.org/
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant dose unit of measure UCUM code
cdes.definitionDescription: Code that represents the dosage unit of measure of the prior or concomitant medication administered. Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM).
cdes.instructions: Code the unit of measure of the medication dosage using Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM). Core for all prospective intervention and observation studies
cdes.referrences: Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM) - http://unitsofmeasure.org/
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant dose unit of measure UCUM code

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant start date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: The date (and time, if applicable and known) on which the prior/concomitant medication usage began.
cdes.questionText: Start Date
cdes.instructions: Record the date (and time) the participant/subject started taking the medication. Start Date can be used to distinguish between prior medications and concomitant medications.  Core for all prospective intervention and observation studies. Record the date/time according to the ISO 8601, the International Standard for the representation of dates and times (http://www.iso.org/iso/home.html).  The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.).
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant start date and time

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant end date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: The date (and time, if applicable and known) the administration of the prior/concomitant medication ended.
cdes.questionText: End Date
cdes.instructions:
Record the date (and time) the participant/subject stopped taking the medication. The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.) and in the format acceptable to the study database. Stop Date should be recorded if Ongoing Medication is answered No. Conversely, Stop Date should remain blank if Ongoing Medication is answered Yes.
Core for all prospective intervention  and observation studies
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant end date and time

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant ongoing indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator of or description that the prior/concomitant medication usage is ongoing.
cdes.questionText: N/A - Ongoing?
cdes.instructions:
Choose one. Answer YES if the participant/subject is still taking the medication or NO if the participant/subject has stopped taking the medication.
Core for all prospective intervention  and observation studies
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant ongoing indicator

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant indication text
cdes.definitionDescription: Text describing reason for administration of a prior/concomitant (nonstudy) agent or measure. This is not the pharmacologic classification of an agent (antibiotic, analgesic, etc.), but the reason for its administration to the participant/subject.
cdes.questionText: Indication
cdes.instructions: Record the reason the participant/subject gives for taking the medication. If given for an Adverse Event (AE), enter exact term from Adverse Event CRF. The indication for the AED medication should be recorded in the database as  epileptic seizure control  to distinguish the AEDs from other prior or concomitant medications taken during the study.  The indication does NOT need to be recorded on the CRF. Core for all prospective intervention and observation studies
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant indication text

cdes.instructions: Choose only one. Indicate if stiffness was felt within the last 24 hours

crfModuleGuideline: Non-Motor Symptom assessment scale for Parkinson's Disease (NMSS)
description: The Non-Motor Symptoms Scale (NMSS) is an instrument specifically designed for the comprehensive assessment of nonmotor symptoms (NMS) in patients with Parkinson's disease.

cdes.cdeName: Non-Motor Symptom assessment scale for Parkinson's Disease (NMSS) - dizziness severity score
cdes.definitionDescription: The severity of the participant/subject experiencing light-headedness, dizziness, weakness on standing from sitting or lying position as part of the Non-Motor Symptom assessment scale for Parkinson's Disease (NMSS).
cdes.questionText: Does the patient experience light-headedness dizziness weakness on standing from sitting or lying position?
cdes.permissibleDescription: None;mild: symptoms present but causes little distress or disturbance to patient;moderate: some distress or disturbance to patient;severe: major source of distress or disturbance to patient;
cdes.instructions: No instructions available
cdes.referrences: Martinex-Martin P, Rodriguez-Blazquez C, Bhattacharya KB, et al. International Study on the psychometric attributes of the Non-Motor Symptoms Scale in Parkinson Disease. Neurology 2009; 73:1584-1591.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Non-Motor Symptom assessment scale for Parkinson's Disease (NMSS)

cdes.questionText: Does the patient experience light-headedness dizziness weakness on standing from sitting or lying position?
cdes.permissibleDescription: rarely (<1/wk);often (1/wk);frequent (several times per week);very frequent (daily or all the time);
cdes.instructions: No instructions available
cdes.referrences: Martinex-Martin P, Rodriguez-Blazquez C, Bhattacharya KB, et al. International Study on the psychometric attributes of the Non-Motor Symptoms Scale in Parkinson Disease. Neurology 2009; 73:1584-1591.

cdes.cdeName: Parkinson's Disease Non Motor Symptoms (PD NMS) - dribbling saliva daytime indicator

cdes.questionText: Dribbling of saliva during the daytime
cdes.instructions: A range of problems is listed. Please tick the box 'Yes' if you have experienced it during the past month. If you have not experienced the problem in the past month tick the box 'No'. You should answer 'No' even if you have had the problem in the past but not in the past month.
cdes.referrences: Developed and validated by the international PD Non Motor Group For information contact: susanne.tluk@uhl.nhs.uk or alison.forbes@uhl.nhs.uk

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant start date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: The date (and time, if applicable and known) on which the prior/concomitant medication usage began.
cdes.questionText: Start Date
cdes.instructions: Record the date (and time) the participant/subject started taking the medication. The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.) and in the format acceptable to the study database. Start Date can be used to distinguish between prior medications and concomitant medications.
cdes.referrences: ISO 8601 - http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue.htm
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant start date and time

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant end date and time
cdes.definitionDescription: The date (and time, if applicable and known) the administration of the prior/concomitant medication ended.
cdes.questionText: End Date
cdes.instructions: Record the date (and time) the participant/subject stopped taking the medication. The date/time should be recorded to the level of granularity known (e.g., year, year and month, complete date plus hours and minutes, etc.) and in the format acceptable to the study database. Stop Date should be recorded if Continuing Medication is answered No. Conversely, Stop Date should remain blank if Continuing Medication is answered Yes.
cdes.referrences: ISO 8601 - http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_catalogue.htm
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication prior or concomitant end date and time

cdes.questionText: If PRN, Average Frequency
cdes.permissibleDescription: twice daily;three times a day;four times a day;every 2 hours;every 4 hours;every 6 hours;every 8 hours;one dose in morning;one dose in evening;once daily;alternating day (every other day);at bedtime;as needed;Other, specify;unknown;Not applicable;
cdes.instructions: Only answer if the medication is taken PRN.

cdes.cdeName: Medication prior or concomitant indication text
cdes.definitionDescription: Text describing reason for administration of a prior/concomitant (nonstudy) agent or measure. This is not the pharmacologic classification of an agent (antibiotic, analgesic, etc.), but the reason for its administration to the participant/subject.

description: Nonverbal Selective Reminding Test (NVSRT)

crfModuleGuideline: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method Short Form
description: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method-Short Form (OSU TBI-ID-SF) is a shortened version of a structured interview developed using recommendations from the CDC for the detection of history of exposure to traumatic brain injury. It elicits self- or proxy-reports of TBI occurring over a person's lifetime according to selected summary indices.

cdes.cdeName: Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS) - identification method hospitalization indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Number and cause of injuries to head or neck that which subject endured and had to go to a hospital or emergency room as part of Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS).
cdes.questionText: Have you ever been hospitalized or treated in an emergency room following an injury to your head or neck? Think about any childhood injuries you remember or were told about.
cdes.instructions: No instructions available
cdes.referrences: Adapted with permission from the Ohio State University TBI Identification Method [Corrigan JD, Bogner JA. Initial reliability and validity of the OSU TBI Identification Method. J Head Trauma Rehabil. Nov-Dec 2007;22(6):318-329. copyright reserved 2007, The Ohio Valley Center for Brain Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation]
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method Short Form
cdes.size: OSU TBI ID SF Scoring Q1

cdes.cdeName: Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS) - worst injury result
cdes.definitionDescription: Result to whether the subject has: 1 an  improbable TBI , 2 a  possible TBI , 3 a  mild TBI , 4 a  moderate TBI , or 5 a  severe TBI  as part of Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS).
cdes.questionText: Worst Injury
cdes.instructions: If in response to #6a and 6b reports never having LOC,  being dazed or having memory lapses classify as 1 improbable TBI. If in response to #6b reports being dazed or having a memory lapse classify as 2 possible TBI. If in response to #6a loss of consciousness (LOC) does not exceed 30 minutes for any injury classify as 3 mild TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury is between 30 minutes and 24 hours classify as 4 moderate TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury exceeds 24 hours classify as 5 severe TBI.
cdes.referrences: Adapted with permission from the Ohio State University TBI Identification Method [Corrigan JD, Bogner JA. Initial reliability and validity of the OSU TBI Identification Method. J Head Trauma Rehabil. Nov-Dec 2007;22(6):318-329. copyright reserved 2007, The Ohio Valley Center for Brain Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation]

crfModuleGuideline: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method Short Form
description: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method-Short Form (OSU TBI-ID-SF) is a shortened version of a structured interview developed using recommendations from the CDC for the detection of history of exposure to traumatic brain injury. It elicits self- or proxy-reports of TBI occurring over a person's lifetime according to selected summary indices.

cdes.questionText: Have you ever been hospitalized or treated in an emergency room following an injury to your head or neck? Think about any childhood injuries you remember or were told about.

cdes.cdeName: Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS) - worst injury result
cdes.definitionDescription: Result to whether the subject has: 1 an  improbable TBI , 2 a  possible TBI , 3 a  mild TBI , 4 a  moderate TBI , or 5 a  severe TBI  as part of Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS).
cdes.questionText: Worst Injury
cdes.instructions: If in response to #6a and 6b reports never having LOC,  being dazed or having memory lapses classify as 1 improbable TBI. If in response to #6b reports being dazed or having a memory lapse classify as 2 possible TBI. If in response to #6a loss of consciousness (LOC) does not exceed 30 minutes for any injury classify as 3 mild TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury is between 30 minutes and 24 hours classify as 4 moderate TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury exceeds 24 hours classify as 5 severe TBI.
cdes.referrences: Adapted with permission from the Ohio State University TBI Identification Method [Corrigan JD, Bogner JA. Initial reliability and validity of the OSU TBI Identification Method. J Head Trauma Rehabil. Nov-Dec 2007;22(6):318-329. copyright reserved 2007, The Ohio Valley Center for Brain Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation]

cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method Short Form

crfModuleGuideline: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method Short Form
description: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method-Short Form (OSU TBI-ID-SF) is a shortened version of a structured interview developed using recommendations from the CDC for the detection of history of exposure to traumatic brain injury. It elicits self- or proxy-reports of TBI occurring over a person's lifetime according to selected summary indices.

cdes.cdeName: Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS) - worst injury result
cdes.definitionDescription: Result to whether the subject has: 1 an  improbable TBI , 2 a  possible TBI , 3 a  mild TBI , 4 a  moderate TBI , or 5 a  severe TBI  as part of Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS).
cdes.questionText: Worst Injury
cdes.instructions: If in response to #6a and 6b reports never having LOC,  being dazed or having memory lapses classify as 1 improbable TBI. If in response to #6b reports being dazed or having a memory lapse classify as 2 possible TBI. If in response to #6a loss of consciousness (LOC) does not exceed 30 minutes for any injury classify as 3 mild TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury is between 30 minutes and 24 hours classify as 4 moderate TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury exceeds 24 hours classify as 5 severe TBI.
cdes.referrences: Adapted with permission from the Ohio State University TBI Identification Method [Corrigan JD, Bogner JA. Initial reliability and validity of the OSU TBI Identification Method. J Head Trauma Rehabil. Nov-Dec 2007;22(6):318-329. copyright reserved 2007, The Ohio Valley Center for Brain Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation]
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method Short Form

crfModuleGuideline: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method Short Form
description: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method-Short Form (OSU TBI-ID-SF) is a shortened version of a structured interview developed using recommendations from the CDC for the detection of history of exposure to traumatic brain injury. It elicits self- or proxy-reports of TBI occurring over a person's lifetime according to selected summary indices.

cdes.questionText: Have you ever been hospitalized or treated in an emergency room following an injury to your head or neck? Think about any childhood injuries you remember or were told about.

cdes.cdeName: Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS) - ask question category
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicator of whether or not subject has lost consciousness and for how long and if not whether subject was dazed or has a gap in their memory from the injury. Also indicates how old the subject was as part of Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS).
cdes.questionText: If all above are no then proceed to question 7. If answered yes to any of the questions above ask the following for each injury Were you knocked or did you lose consciousness LOC? If yes how long? If no were you dazed or did you have a gap in your memory
cdes.instructions: See instructions on form

If in response to #6b reports being dazed or having a memory lapse classify as 2 possible TBI. If in response to #6a loss of consciousness (LOC) does not exceed 30 minutes for any injury classify as 3 mild TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury is between 30 minutes and 24 hours classify as 4 moderate TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury exceeds 24 hours classify as 5 severe TBI.
cdes.referrences: Adapted with permission from the Ohio State University TBI Identification Method [Corrigan JD, Bogner JA. Initial reliability and validity of the OSU TBI Identification Method. cdes.cdeName: Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS) - worst injury result
cdes.definitionDescription: Result to whether the subject has: 1 an  improbable TBI , 2 a  possible TBI , 3 a  mild TBI , 4 a  moderate TBI , or 5 a  severe TBI  as part of Ohio State TBI Method Short Form (OSUTBIMS).
cdes.questionText: Worst Injury
cdes.instructions: If in response to #6a and 6b reports never having LOC,  being dazed or having memory lapses classify as 1 improbable TBI. If in response to #6b reports being dazed or having a memory lapse classify as 2 possible TBI. If in response to #6a loss of consciousness (LOC) does not exceed 30 minutes for any injury classify as 3 mild TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury is between 30 minutes and 24 hours classify as 4 moderate TBI. If in response to #6a LOC for any one injury exceeds 24 hours classify as 5 severe TBI.
cdes.referrences: Adapted with permission from the Ohio State University TBI Identification Method [Corrigan JD, Bogner JA. Initial reliability and validity of the OSU TBI Identification Method. J Head Trauma Rehabil. Nov-Dec 2007;22(6):318-329. copyright reserved 2007, The Ohio Valley Center for Brain Injury Prevention and Rehabilitation]

cdes.crfModuleGuideline: Ohio State University TBI Identification Method Short Form

cdes.cdeName: Comfort care indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Indicates if there is any evidence that the participant's/ subject's care was restricted to  Comfort Measures Only .  Commonly referred to as  palliative care  in the medical community and  comfort care  by the general public. Palliative care includes attention to the psychological and spiritual needs of the patient and support for the dying patient and the patient's family.
cdes.questionText: Was the participant's/subject's care restricted to  Comfort Measures Only
cdes.instructions: Choose one
cdes.referrences: Get With The Guidelines (GWTG) Stroke Patient Management Tool Coding Instructions (Updated on 11/4/2009); Paul Coverdell National Acute Stroke Registry

cdes.permissibleDescription: The earliest day the physician/APN/PA documented comfort measures only was the day of arrival (Day 1) or day after arrival (Day 2).;The earliest day the physician/APN/PA documented comfort measures only was two or more days after arrival day (Day 3+).;There is physician/APN/PA documentation of comfort measures only during this hospital stay, but whether the earliest documentation of comfort measures only was on day 1 or 2 OR after day 2 is unclear.;Not Documented/ Unable To Determine: There is no physician/APN/PA documentation of comfort measures only, or unable to determine from medical record documentation.;
cdes.instructions: Choose one

cdes.cdeName: Comfort care measure type
cdes.definitionDescription: Describes the types of comfort care the participant/ subject received
cdes.questionText: Type(s) of comfort care measures received
cdes.permissibleValue: Eliminating sources of discomfort;Providing effective pain and symptom management through the use of medications and other therapies;Offering a quiet, private environment that supports the intimate process of dying;Encouraging personal rituals that may honor or celebrate the person dying;Providing support, reassurance, and information about grief, bereavement, and information and guidance about the dying process;Providing spiritual care as desired;Offering food and fluids as the dying person desires and is able to take;Preventing constipation, even if oral intake has been minimal;Positioning at frequent intervals to prevent bedsores;Offering frequent mouth care for discomfort from drying (as tolerated);Instilling artificial tears or eye lubricant for discomfort from drying;Limiting vital signs to respirations (breathing) and temperature (this practice may vary);Stopping medications that are not essential to promoting comfort, including antibiotics;Stopping needle sticks and blood draws, including finger sticks for blood sugar;Removing nonessential equipment that may distract care providers and loved ones from focusing on the one who is dying;Other, specify;
cdes.permissibleDescription: Eliminating sources of discomfort;Providing effective pain and symptom management through the use of medications and other therapies;Offering a quiet, private environment that supports the intimate process of dying;Encouraging personal rituals that may honor or celebrate the person dying;Providing support, reassurance, and information about grief, bereavement, and information and guidance about the dying process;Providing spiritual care as desired;Offering food and fluids as the dying person desires and is able to take;Preventing constipation, even if oral intake has been minimal;Positioning at frequent intervals to prevent bedsores;Offering frequent mouth care for discomfort from drying (as tolerated);Instilling artificial tears or eye lubricant for discomfort from drying;Limiting vital signs to respirations (breathing) and temperature (this practice may vary);Stopping medications that are not essential to promoting comfort, including antibiotics;Stopping needle sticks and blood draws, including finger sticks for blood sugar;Removing nonessential equipment that may distract care providers and loved ones from focusing on the one who is dying (e.g.,  cardiac monitors, feeding tubes and tube feedings, IV access devices, Foley catheters, etc.);Other, specify;
cdes.instructions: Choose all that apply

cdes.cdeName: Spot sign count
cdes.definitionDescription: The number of  spot sign  on computed tomography (CT) angiography to identify patients with intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) who are at high risk for hematoma expansion.  Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), a CT angiography spot sign (i.e., active contrast extravasation) indicates a high risk of hematoma expansion. The computed tomogram angiography (CTA) 'spot sign' describes foci of intralesional enhancement associated with hematoma expansion in primary intracerebral hemorrhage patients.
cdes.questionText: Number of spot signs
cdes.instructions: Contains data elements collected when an imaging study is performed to measure parenchyma; data recorded attempt to divide the strokes into ischemic or hemorrhagic subtypes, as distinction of hemorrhage versus infarction is the initial critical branch point in acute stroke triage.  (Examples of CDEs included: Acute infarcts present; Planimetic acute ischemic lesion volume; and Acute hematoma present)
cdes.referrences: Thompson AL, Kosior JC, Gladstone DJ, Hopyan JJ, Symons SP, Romero F, Dzialowski I, Roy J, Demchuk AM, Aviv RI; PREDICTS/Sunnybrook ICH CTA Study Group (2009). Defining the CT angiography 'spot sign' in primary intracerebral hemorrhage. Can J Neurol Sci. 36(4):456-61; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19650356
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined

cdes.cdeName: Spot sign maximum attenuation score
cdes.definitionDescription: The maximum attenuation score for  spot sign  on computed tomography (CT) angiography to identify patients with intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) who are at high risk for hematoma expansion.  Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH), a CT angiography spot sign (i.e., active contrast extravasation) indicates a high risk of hematoma expansion
cdes.questionText: Maximum attenuation
cdes.instructions:
Contains data elements collected when an imaging study is performed to measure parenchyma; data recorded attempt to divide the strokes into ischemic or hemorrhagic subtypes, as distinction of hemorrhage versus infarction is the initial critical branch point in acute stroke triage.  (Examples of CDEs included: Acute infarcts present; Planimetic acute ischemic lesion volume; and Acute hematoma present)
Thompson et al definition:
Used specific windows (Width 177, Level 77)
Spot-like and/or serpiginous focus of enhancement
Within the margin of a hematoma without connection to outside vessels
>1.5 mm in maximal dimension
Hounsfield unit density at least double that of background hematoma
Delgado Almondez et al definition:
Used specific windows (Width 200, Level 110)
Any size and morphology
Discontinuous from normal or abnormal vasculature adjacent to the ICH
=1 focus of contrast pooling within the ICH
Hounsfield unit density at least 120 HU
cdes.referrences:
Thompson AL, Kosior JC, Gladstone DJ, Hopyan JJ, Symons SP, Romero F, Dzialowski I, Roy J, Demchuk AM, Aviv RI; PREDICTS/Sunnybrook ICH CTA Study Group (2009). Defining the CT angiography 'spot sign' in primary intracerebral hemorrhage. Can J Neurol Sci. 36(4):456-61; http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19650356
Delgado, Almondez et al, Stroke2009

cdes.cdeName: Epidural hematoma status
cdes.definitionDescription: Status of a collection of blood between the skull and dura.  On CT, the EDH typically (though not always) has a biconvex shape, an adjacent skull fracture/scalp injury, and classically does not cross sutural margins.   (In patients with skull fractures, especially those in children involving the sutures, this rule may not always apply.) The acute EDH is hyperdense, but may contain hypodense areas representing unclotted blood.   As the EDH evolves, it gradually loses its hyperdensity and may appear iso/hypodense.  On MRI, the acute EDH is hypo/isointense on T1 and very hypointense on T2, GRE, and SW-imaging.  The inwardly displaced dura should be directly visualized on MR as a thin dark line on all pulse sequences.
cdes.questionText: Epidural Hematoma
cdes.instructions: Contains data elements collected when an imaging study is performed to measure parenchyma; data recorded attempt to divide the strokes into ischemic or hemorrhagic subtypes, as distinction of hemorrhage versus infarction is the initial critical branch point in acute stroke triage.  (Examples of CDEs included: Acute infarcts present; Planimetic acute ischemic lesion volume; and Acute hematoma present)

cdes.instructions: Contains data elements collected when an imaging study is performed to measure parenchyma; data recorded attempt to divide the strokes into ischemic or hemorrhagic subtypes, as distinction of hemorrhage versus infarction is the initial critical branch point in acute stroke triage. cdes.cdeName: Parkinson's Disease medication side effect text
cdes.definitionDescription: Type(s) of side effect experienced by participant/subject from the prior or concomitant anti-Parkinson's Disease medication
cdes.questionText: Side Effects
cdes.instructions: Please refer to the Common Side Effects chart for the codes of the possible side effects experienced from PD medications. Only capture the side effects code on this form. Specifics of the side effect (i.e., Severity, Relatedness, Outcome, etc) should be recorded on the General Adverse Events form if they occur during the study. Common Side Effects Chart:AA=Motor  offs (including wearing off and sudden off); BB=Dyskinesia;CC=Hallucination/psychosis; DD=Cognitive impairment  not dementia; EE=Non-motor offs, specify; FF=Behavioral disturbances, specify; GG=Autonomic dysfunction; HH=Daytime sleep abnormalities;II= Nighttime sleep abnormalities; JJ=ICD (including Gambling, Hypersexuality, Binge eating, Shopping);KK=Punding;LL=Dopadysregulation syndrome;MM=Dopamine agonist withdrawal;OT=Other important side effects, specify
cdes.referrences: No references available
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.previousTitle: Medication Parkinsonian prior or concomitant side effect type

crfModuleGuideline: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Questionnaire (PDQL)
Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life Scale (PDQUALIF)
description: Contains data elements related to non-motor symptoms of PD. (Examples of CDEs included: balance, exercise, social activities, and sleep).

cdes.cdeName: Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life (PDQUALIF) - lightheaded scale
cdes.definitionDescription: Rating scale for  lightheaded symptom caused by changing positions (lying to standing, or sitting to standing) as part of Parkinson's Disease Quality of Life (PDQUALIF) form
cdes.questionText: Changing positions causes me to become lightheaded (lying to standing, or sitting to standing)
cdes.instructions: Select the answer which best describes your personal situation.  Note: If at least one CDE was selected from a copyright- or trademark-protected instrument/scale then all of the CDEs from that instrument/scale are included in this report. The instrument may not be reproduced or translated in whole or in part without the express written permission of the lead author, Mickie Welsh.  See http://pdqualif.com for full terms and use and licensing information.

cdes.cdeName: Parkinson's Disease Sleep Scale (PDSS) - sleep well scale
cdes.definitionDescription: Scale assessing how often the participant slept well during the past week (7 days), as part of the Parkinson's Disease Sleep Scale (PDSS).
cdes.questionText: Overall, did you sleep well during the last week?
cdes.permissibleDescription: Very often (this means 6 to 7 days a week);Often (this means 4 to 5 days a week);Sometimes (this means 2 to 3 days a week);occasionally (this means 1 day a week);Never;
cdes.instructions: Please rate the severity of the following based on your experiences during the past week (7 days). Please make a cross in the answer box.
cdes.referrences: Perez LS, Rossi M, Cardinali DP, Merello M. Validation of the sleep related items of the Non-motor Symptoms Questionnaire for Parkinson's disease (NMSQuest). Parkinsonism Relat Disord 2008;14:641-645.  Bastien CH, Vallieres A, Morin CM. Validation of the Insomnia Severity Index as an outcome measure for insomnia research. Sleep Med 2001;2:297-307.  Revised version 1.0 / 22.10.2006 /  Chaudhuri KR, Trenkwalder C, Kohnen R, 2006.  For request: Ray.Chaudhuri@kingsch.nhs.uk

description: The 10 item scale measures the impact of Parkinson's disease. This disease specific measure can be completed by the subject or by an interviewer. It is intended for a patient but has been validated in caregivers as well. It has four domains: physical aspects of disease (5 items), psychological aspects (2 items), social aspects (2 items) and sexuality (2 items).

description: The Participant/Subject Contact Information CRF Module records the contact information for the study participant/subject. The template form also has a place to record the contact information for persons who regularly interact with the subject. The contact information data are not part of the clinical data management system so as to protect the identity of study participants, but rather are kept in a locked location for authorized study personnel to reference.

description: The PART-O consists of 19 items asking for the frequency that the person engages in various activities within the community. Scores have been standardized based on a population sample. Several scoring options have been examined, providing a total score and 3 subscale scores. A briefer 12-item version is currently being evaluated.

cdes.cdeName: Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective (PART-O) - Active homemake time score
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the number of hours in a typical week the participant/subject will spend in active homemaking, including cleaning, cooking, and raising children as part of Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools - Objective (PART-O).
cdes.questionText: In a typical week how many hours do you spend in active homemaking including cleaning, cooking and raising children?
cdes.permissibleDescription: None;1-4 hours;5-9 hours;10-19 hours;20-34 hours;35 or more hours;Don't Know/not sure/refused;
cdes.instructions: See instructions on form.  Capture total score only for this measure.
cdes.referrences: Instrument: Whiteneck GG, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW, Bogner JA, Bushnik T, Cicerone KD, Corrigan JD, Hart T, Malec JF, Millis SR. Development of the Participation Assessment With Recombined Tools-Objective for use after traumatic brain injury. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:542-51.  Scoring: Bogner JA, Whiteneck GG, Corrigan JD, Lai J-S, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW. Comparison of scoring methods for the Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:552-63.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.domain: Social Role Participation and Social Competence

cdes.cdeName: Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective (PART-O) - Live significant other indicator score
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for indicating whether the participant/subject lives with a spouse or a significant other as part of Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools - Objective (PART-O).
cdes.questionText: Switching now to a somewhat different kind of questionDo you live with your spouse or significant other?
cdes.instructions: If YES, skip to PART Question 17; if NO, ask QUESTION 16; When Item 15 is Yes, assign score of 5 to both Q15 and Q16, for a total of 10 points. This results in assignment of 10 points for living with a spouse, 5 points for being in an intimate, non-marital relationship, and 0 points if neither is applicable.

cdes.cdeName: Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective (PART-O) - Average total score
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the average of the combined score of each of the answered questions about productivity, social relations, and out and about as part of Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools - Objective (PART-O).
cdes.questionText: Averaged Total Score
cdes.instructions: Calculate domain scores: Productivity =(PART-O 1 (work)+PART-O 2 (school)+PART-O 3 (homemaking))/3; Social Relations=(PART-O 4 (friends)+ PART-O 5 (family) + PART-O 6 (emotional support)  + PART-O 7 (internet) + PART-O 15 (spouse) + PART-O 16 (intimate relationship) + PART-O 17 (close friend))/7; Out and About= (PART-O 8 (days out) + PART-O 9 (eat out) + PART-O 10 (shop) + PART-O 11 (engages sports) + PART-O 12 (movies) + PART-O 13 (attend sports) + PART-O 14 (church))/7; Calculate total scores: PART-O Averaged Total Score =(Productivity + Social Relations +Out and About)/3.
cdes.referrences: Instrument: Whiteneck GG, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW, Bogner JA, Bushnik T, Cicerone KD, Corrigan JD, Hart T, Malec JF, Millis SR. Development of the Participation Assessment With Recombined Tools-Objective for use after traumatic brain injury. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:542-51.  Scoring: Bogner JA, Whiteneck GG, Corrigan JD, Lai J-S, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW. Comparison of scoring methods for the Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:552-63.

description: The PART-O consists of 19 items asking for the frequency that the person engages in various activities within the community. Scores have been standardized based on a population sample. cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the average of the combined score of each of the answered questions about productivity, social relations, and out and about as part of Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools - Objective (PART-O).
cdes.questionText: Averaged Total Score
cdes.instructions: Calculate domain scores: Productivity =(PART-O 1 (work)+PART-O 2 (school)+PART-O 3 (homemaking))/3; Social Relations=(PART-O 4 (friends)+ PART-O 5 (family) + PART-O 6 (emotional support)  + PART-O 7 (internet) + PART-O 15 (spouse) + PART-O 16 (intimate relationship) + PART-O 17 (close friend))/7; Out and About= (PART-O 8 (days out) + PART-O 9 (eat out) + PART-O 10 (shop) + PART-O 11 (engages sports) + PART-O 12 (movies) + PART-O 13 (attend sports) + PART-O 14 (church))/7; Calculate total scores: PART-O Averaged Total Score =(Productivity + Social Relations +Out and About)/3.
cdes.referrences: Instrument: Whiteneck GG, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW, Bogner JA, Bushnik T, Cicerone KD, Corrigan JD, Hart T, Malec JF, Millis SR. Development of the Participation Assessment With Recombined Tools-Objective for use after traumatic brain injury. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:542-51.  Scoring: Bogner JA, Whiteneck GG, Corrigan JD, Lai J-S, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW. Comparison of scoring methods for the Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:552-63.

cdes.definitionDescription: Score for indicating whether the participant/subject lives with a spouse or a significant other as part of Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools - Objective (PART-O).
cdes.questionText: Switching now to a somewhat different kind of questionDo you live with your spouse or significant other?
cdes.instructions: If YES, skip to PART Question 17; if NO, ask QUESTION 16; When Item 15 is Yes, assign score of 5 to both Q15 and Q16, for a total of 10 points. This results in assignment of 10 points for living with a spouse, 5 points for being in an intimate, non-marital relationship, and 0 points if neither is applicable.

cdes.cdeName: Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective (PART-O) - Live significant other indicator score
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for indicating whether the participant/subject lives with a spouse or a significant other as part of Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools - Objective (PART-O).
cdes.questionText: Switching now to a somewhat different kind of questionDo you live with your spouse or significant other?
cdes.instructions: If YES, skip to PART Question 17; if NO, ask QUESTION 16; When Item 15 is Yes, assign score of 5 to both Q15 and Q16, for a total of 10 points. This results in assignment of 10 points for living with a spouse, 5 points for being in an intimate, non-marital relationship, and 0 points if neither is applicable.

cdes.cdeName: Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective (PART-O) - Average total score
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the average of the combined score of each of the answered questions about productivity, social relations, and out and about as part of Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools - Objective (PART-O).
cdes.questionText: Averaged Total Score
cdes.instructions: Calculate domain scores: Productivity =(PART-O 1 (work)+PART-O 2 (school)+PART-O 3 (homemaking))/3; Social Relations=(PART-O 4 (friends)+ PART-O 5 (family) + PART-O 6 (emotional support)  + PART-O 7 (internet) + PART-O 15 (spouse) + PART-O 16 (intimate relationship) + PART-O 17 (close friend))/7; Out and About= (PART-O 8 (days out) + PART-O 9 (eat out) + PART-O 10 (shop) + PART-O 11 (engages sports) + PART-O 12 (movies) + PART-O 13 (attend sports) + PART-O 14 (church))/7; Calculate total scores: PART-O Averaged Total Score =(Productivity + Social Relations +Out and About)/3.
cdes.referrences: Instrument: Whiteneck GG, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW, Bogner JA, Bushnik T, Cicerone KD, Corrigan JD, Hart T, Malec JF, Millis SR. Development of the Participation Assessment With Recombined Tools-Objective for use after traumatic brain injury. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:542-51.  Scoring: Bogner JA, Whiteneck GG, Corrigan JD, Lai J-S, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW. Comparison of scoring methods for the Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:552-63.

description: The PART-O consists of 19 items asking for the frequency that the person engages in various activities within the community. Scores have been standardized based on a population sample. Several scoring options have been examined, providing a total score and 3 subscale scores. A briefer 12-item version is currently being evaluated.

cdes.cdeName: Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective (PART-O) - Live significant other indicator score
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for indicating whether the participant/subject lives with a spouse or a significant other as part of Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools - Objective (PART-O).
cdes.questionText: Switching now to a somewhat different kind of questionDo you live with your spouse or significant other?
cdes.instructions: If YES, skip to PART Question 17; if NO, ask QUESTION 16; When Item 15 is Yes, assign score of 5 to both Q15 and Q16, for a total of 10 points. This results in assignment of 10 points for living with a spouse, 5 points for being in an intimate, non-marital relationship, and 0 points if neither is applicable.

cdes.cdeName: Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective (PART-O) - Average total score
cdes.definitionDescription: Score for the average of the combined score of each of the answered questions about productivity, social relations, and out and about as part of Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools - Objective (PART-O).
cdes.questionText: Averaged Total Score
cdes.instructions: Calculate domain scores: Productivity =(PART-O 1 (work)+PART-O 2 (school)+PART-O 3 (homemaking))/3; Social Relations=(PART-O 4 (friends)+ PART-O 5 (family) + PART-O 6 (emotional support)  + PART-O 7 (internet) + PART-O 15 (spouse) + PART-O 16 (intimate relationship) + PART-O 17 (close friend))/7; Out and About= (PART-O 8 (days out) + PART-O 9 (eat out) + PART-O 10 (shop) + PART-O 11 (engages sports) + PART-O 12 (movies) + PART-O 13 (attend sports) + PART-O 14 (church))/7; Calculate total scores: PART-O Averaged Total Score =(Productivity + Social Relations +Out and About)/3.
cdes.referrences: Instrument: Whiteneck GG, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW, Bogner JA, Bushnik T, Cicerone KD, Corrigan JD, Hart T, Malec JF, Millis SR. Development of the Participation Assessment With Recombined Tools-Objective for use after traumatic brain injury. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:542-51.  Scoring: Bogner JA, Whiteneck GG, Corrigan JD, Lai J-S, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW. Comparison of scoring methods for the Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:552-63.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.domain: Social Role Participation and Social Competence

cdes.permissibleDescription: 1 time;2 times;3 times;4 times;5 or more times;Don't Know/Not Sure;Refused;None;
cdes.instructions: See instructions on form.  Capture total score only for this measure.
cdes.referrences: Instrument: Whiteneck GG, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW, Bogner JA, Bushnik T, Cicerone KD, Corrigan JD, Hart T, Malec JF, Millis SR. Development of the Participation Assessment With Recombined Tools-Objective for use after traumatic brain injury. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:542-51.  Scoring: Bogner JA, Whiteneck GG, Corrigan JD, Lai J-S, Dijkers MP, Heinemann AW. Comparison of scoring methods for the Participation Assessment with Recombined Tools-Objective. Arch Phys Med Rehabil 2011;92:552-63.
cdes.aliasesForVariableName: Aliases for variable name not defined
cdes.subDomain: Social Role Participation and Social Competence

cdes.cdeName: Classes last 3 months indicator
cdes.definitionDescription: Now I'd like you to think about the last 3 months. In that time, have you taken adult education classes, GED classes, continuing education, special courses, or used other opportunities for learning, for example, seminars or conferences?
cdes.questionText: Now I'd like you to think about the last 3 months. In that time, have you taken adult education classes, GED classes, continuing education, special courses, or used other opportunities for learning, for example, seminars or conferences?
